title: Telco reform on PM's agenda as he rails against 'negative globalism'
text:
"But Australia's interests will determine our involvement and we won't be copping from any global organisation or institution any instructions or directions that are at odds with our national interest or with any presumption that some global agenda is bigger than Australia."

During his speech to the Lowy Institute on Thursday, Mr Morrison said Australia's national interests were not served by isolationism or protectionism, and did not advocate withdrawing from international bodies.

He promised that Australia would take a more active role in setting global rules, particularly on commerce, trade and investment, and not being dictated to by unelected bureaucrats.

Mr Morrison's speech was widely seen as a swipe at the United Nations' frequent attacks on the government's hardline border protection policies as illegal and inhumane, as well as repudiation of criticism Australia was a laggard on climate change.

But he also reiterated his view that global economic rules had not kept up with China's rise to become a newly developed economy.

While Mr Morrison last month called on China to lose WTO concessions it can receive as a developing country, it is understood he also has concerns over other global economic rule-making forums in the postal and telecommunications industries.

Last month, the UN's Universal Postal Union – which sets standards for mail – avoided collapse after bowing to the Trump administration's demands to increase delivery fees after the US Postal Service effectively subsidised the delivery of cheap goods from China.

And the UN's International Telecommunication Union, which oversees telephone and internet services, is expected this year to issue standards on 5G technology.

Advertisement

The head of the agency, Chinese bureaucrat Zhao Houlin, earlier this year said security concerns over controversial Chinese technology company Huawei appeared to be driven more by politics and there was no evidence the firm should be blacklisted. Australia was the first country to ban Huawei from participating in its 5G rollout.

An area where Australia has taken a global lead is regulation of blockchain, seeking input from a raft of countries including China on setting standards that work worldwide.

Opposition Leader Anthony Albanese said Mr Morrison's speech was a distraction from the domestic economic woes facing Australians.

"On international issues it's absurd to suggest that somehow voluntary agreements that Australia signs up to are imposed by bureaucracies or international organisations such as the United Nations," he said.

Deputy Labor leader Richard Marles said that a host of problems required global solutions, such as climate change.

"The sort of nationalistic talk we hear at the moment, in the speech last night and also that we heard from the US President a few weeks ago, I think, is not the right tone at this time," he said.

Australian Institute for International Affairs president Allan Gyngell said Mr Morrison's speech was a shift from the 2017 Foreign Policy white paper, which emphasised multilateralism and defending the global rules-based order.

"There are elements of continuity from earlier things but this had much more of a tone of Trump and Brexit," he said.
description: Labor criticises the PM for a 'nationalistic' tone in his swipe at global institutions.
